plants.name: Aster amellus
plants.description: A perennial herb native to Europe, known for its star-shaped purple or blue flowers that bloom abundantly in late summer to early autumn. It attracts butterflies and bees and is often used in ornamental gardens.
plants.funFact: The name 'Michaelmas Daisy' comes from its peak blooming around the feast of St. Michael (September 29).

plants.name: Erythrina crista-galli
plants.description: A striking small tree native to South America producing vibrant red, bird-attracting flowers with unique shapes resembling a rooster's crest. It blooms primarily in late winter to early spring in the Southern Hemisphere but can bloom into September in some subtropical climates.
plants.funFact: Erythrina crista-galli is the national flower of Argentina and Uruguay.

plants.name: Solidago canadensis
plants.description: A tall, flowering herbaceous perennial native to North America, it produces dense clusters of bright yellow flowers in late summer and fall, commonly found in meadows and along roadsides.
plants.funFact: Goldenrods are important nectar sources for migrating butterflies and beneficial insects.

plants.name: Chrysanthemum morifolium
plants.description: A popular autumn-blooming garden plant originating from East Asia, with flowers available in diverse colors and forms. Chrysanthemums symbolize longevity and rejuvenation in many cultures.
plants.funFact: In Japan, chrysanthemums are celebrated annually in a festival called 'Kiku Matsuri.'
